description: Common principles of Circuits, Systems and flows of electron, photons, and other entities as applied to electrical, and non-electrical systems such as optical (plasmonic), fluidic, traffic, neural, electrochemical, and biological circuits. Class demonstration and computer simulations will be given where applicable to help in rapid understanding of concepts and applications.
name: ELEC CIRCUITS & SYS I

values.comments:
The course covers common principles of circuits, systems and flows of electron,
photons, and other entities as applied to electrical and non-electrical systems such as
optical (plasmonic), fluidic, traffic, neural, electrochemical, and biological circuits. Class
demonstration and computer simulations are given where applicable to help in rapid
understanding of concepts and applications.
This course teaches you how to analyze complex circuit. Students reported this
course being “helpful” and “interesting.” Students stated that this course was “basically a
review of PHYS 151 until the first midterm” and then got into completely new and
interesting topics afterwards.
Professor Lee was highly regarded by his students. Students reported him as
being “great,” an “excellent professor,” and an “awesome lecturer. Students stated that
the course felt rushed towards the end and one suggested that Lee could “cover the first
few chapters much faster and cover the harder material such as phasors in more detail and
for more time.” Students reported Professor Lee and the TAs as both being extremely
helpful and easy to meet with. Students praised Professor Lee for being clear and concise
in his lectures, and coming well prepared to class.
The class generally consisted of undergraduates between freshman and junior year
and requires PHYS 151 experience. Students complained that the final consisted of 45%
of the grade and wished there was a higher grade on homework, which “can take up to 6-
8 hours a week if done properly.” Students in systems engineering reported some
difficulty in the class while electrical systems engineers found this course’s course
content to be fair.
